p: The microemulsion is a thermodynamically stable dispersion of two immiscible liquids in the presence of a surfactant, which forms a monolayer at the interface between oil and water, possibly exhibiting an ultralow interfacial tension [ 27]. In microemulsion, IONPs are typically synthetized by intramicellar nucleation and growth, following the standard procedure exemplified in Figure 3 [ 28]. The physicochemical properties of NPs prepared by such a technique essentially depend upon the choice of the surfactant. Specifically, nanoparticles result in spherical shape, nearly monodispersed, with an average diameter ranging between 10 and 25 nm [ 28, 29]. In this context, water-in-Oil (W/O) microemulsions are called reverse micelles [ 30].
